question: 9 (c)
sols_html:
The Riemann sum formula using the right end points for a function \(f(x)\) is

\(f(x) = R_{n} = \sum_{k=1}^{n}f(x_{k})\Delta x\)

where

\(x_{k} = a + k\Delta x \quad\quad \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}\)

In our example, comparing the terms, we see that

\(\Delta x = \frac{1}{n}\)

and so

\(b-a = 1\)

Also, we have that

\(f(x_{k}) = \ln\left(1 + \frac{k}{n} \right)\)

So taking \(f(x) = \ln(1 + x)\), we have

\(x_{k} = a + k\Delta x = a + \frac{k}{n} = \frac{k}{n}\)

so we have \(a=0\) and hence since \(b - a = 1\) and so \(b = b - 0 = 1\). Plugging all this information in, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \ln\left(1 + \frac{k}{n}\right) = \int_{0}^{1}\ln(1+x)\,dx\end{aligned}\]

The Riemann sum formula using the right end points for a function \(f(x)\) is

\(f(x) = R_{n} = \sum_{k=1}^{n}f(x_{k})\Delta x\)

where

\(x_{k} = a + k\Delta x \quad\quad \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}\)

In our example, comparing the terms, we see that

\(\Delta x = \frac{1}{n}\)

and so

\(b-a = 1\)

Also, we have that

\(f(x_{k}) = \ln\left(1 + \frac{k}{n} \right)\)

So taking \(f(x) = \ln(x)\), we have

\(x_{k} = a + k\Delta x = a + \frac{k}{n} = 1 + \frac{k}{n}\)

so we have \(a=1\) and hence since \(b - a = 1\) and so \(b - 1 = 1\) giving \(b=2\). Plugging all this information in, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \ln\left(1 + \frac{k}{n}\right) = \int_{1}^{2}\ln(x)\,dx\end{aligned}\]
